column42: incident

column17: In the midst of a crisis
column42: The man had been escorted to a bus stop by the staff of a nearby hosptial, where he had been a patient. There, apparently in the midst of a mental health episode, he atacked a guard with a sign post. A Sheriff's Deputy at the hospital rushed to the scene. When confronted by the deputy, the man rushed at him. The deputy shot him several times and the man died at the hospital.

column17: In the midst of a crisis
column42: Police were called to the home of Johannes Melvin Wood for a second time in 24 hours because he was having a mental health crisis. When a deputy arrived, Wood was found holding two knives. The deputy then fired a single shot, killing Wood.

column21: Responded to call of a man driving his car into a ditch.
column42: Police got a report that a car jumping a roadway median and landing in a ditch. When they arrived there was no one in the car. Kenneth Eugene Bonanno, 65, was found nearby with a gun. He fired at deputies, who returned fire. He was later pronounced dead at a nearby hospital.

Willis N. Walker Jr. got into an argument with his estranged wife at her home. She ran to a neighbor's house. Willis followed her and fired a shotgun towards the door of the house. He forced his way inside, shot and killed 74-year-old James Stewart and then violently assaulted his wife.  When police arrived he refuse to listen to their commands and walked towards them with a shotgun. A deputy then shot and killed him.

Police were investigating a seperate incident when they heard a distrubance. They encounted Willie James in a house, where they say they found him with a large kitchen knife. Police say he lunged at them with the knife and that two officers fired. His family says he was unarmed. He was struck and killed.

Police arrived at the scene to serve a custody order on Joshua Brooks, 26. Brooks fired a gun in the house filled with family members. Ultimately he confronted police with a gun and was shot and killed.

Police snipers shot Eric Wakup, 30, after a standoff that lasted several hours. Wakup had fired an "assault-like" weapon at police eight times and had more than a dozen firearms in his house. The incident began when someone who had been “held against his will” in the home made it out, police said.

State Trooper Chad Dermyer was in the midst of interdiction training when he stopped James Brown III, 34, to question him. After about 30 seconds, Brown shot and killed the Dermyer. Two civilians also were shot by Brown. Another trooper then shot and killed the Brown.

column23: Grundy Police Department, Buchanan County Sheriff's Office
column42: Police were called to Terrance Blackburn's residence after someone reported a suicidal man outside firing a weapon. Police say when they arrived there was a confrontation and Blackburn, 36, was shot and killed.

Travis Blair, 33, was pulled over for a traffic stop. He had failed to appear in court to face drug charges the week before. During the stop, Blair put his car in gear and dragged an officer. After crashing the car in a ditch, the officer and Blair got into a struggle. Blair was shot and died several hours later.

Police were called to an apartment complex because Boyd Ballard, 61, was threatening to stab his daughter's boyfriend. When officers arrived, Ballard was in a parking lot carrying two large butcher knives. He refused to drop them and told police to shoot him. An officer fired one shot, killing Ballard.

column21: Police in vicinity, fake gun is pulled.
column42: On an unrelated stakeout, police saw India Beaty, 25, pull what looked like a handgun on an unarmed man in a parking lot. The officers ordered Beaty to drop her weapon. She did not comply and "made a threatening motion," police said. The officers shot her. It turned out it was a fake handgun.

Police were searching for Tyre Privott, 25, who was suspected in a homicide. Two officers spotted Privott on Chesapeake Blvd. and Fishermans Road. Officers said as they started to talk to him, Privott shot at them. One officer returned fire, killing Privott.

column17: Was living ina home for youth with behavioral, emotional or developmental needs.
column21: Report of man with bandanna and gun in parking lot.
column42: Police found Kionte Spencer, 18, in a parking lot with a handgun. Officers twice tried to use stun gun on Spencer. When he turned toward them with gun, officers shot him. After the shooting, police discovered the weapon was a BB gun.

Police were called to a house to investigate a "combative male." When they arrived, Dyzhawn Perkins, 19, jumped through a plate glass window and attacked a deputy. One of the two officers then shot and killed him.

column33: K-9 shot and killed by decedent
column42: Richardson barricaded himself in his house after a fight with his wife. After an eight-hour standoff, he shot and killed a police dog, then was shot and killed by police.
Corey Jason Achstein, 28, threatened a group of teenagers with a gun. He was shot and killed by an officer “based upon actions of the suspect and concern for safety," police said.

During an armed burglary investigation, police stopped a vehicle driven by Jabril Eli Mitchell, 21. Police said Mitchell had a gun, refused to drop it and charged at at officer. Mitchell was shot and killed.
Gregory McCraken, 49, was spotted in a taxi after police received a call that he was suicidal. McCracken shot himself, then turned the gun on officers. He was shot and killed.
A sheriff's deputy was investigating a hit and run when Kenneth Ray Pinter, 45, pulled out a gun and shot the deputy. The deputy, who was wounded, returned fire and killed Pinter.

column17: Police led to believe he was mentally instable.
column42: Called to the home for a disturbance, a police officer found Kenneth Henry Morgan, 64, barricaded inside. Morgan walked toward the officer with a knife in his hand. He was shot and killed.

column23: Powhatan County Sheriff's Office and Virginia State Police
column42: Police shot Franklin Short, 71, who was carrying a gun, at his home. They had responded to a domestic disturbance call.
Police were searching for Kawanza Beaty, 23, after receiving reports that he was armed with a shotgun. Beaty ran from police, who saw a shotgun in his sleeve. Officers shot and killed Beaty.
While investigating a minor car accident, police stopped and questioned Damien Harrell, 26. Harrell gave police a false name, then pulled out a gun. Officers immediately shot and killed him.
John Calvin Chewning, 46, robbed a pharmacy of oxycontin and money. When police officers stopped him, he raised a pellet gun at them. Officers shot and killed him.

Police used a battering ram to knock in William A. Cooper's door in a drug raid. One officer stumbled backward, then saw Cooper, 69, with a gun pointed in his "general direction." Cooper was shot and killed.
Robert L. Henderson III, 21, led police on a car chase. When he stopped, he exited the car with a gas-powered BB gun. An officer shot and killed him.

Virginia State Police were called to the scene of an abandoned vehicle. Herbert J. Wheeler Jr., 32, fled but was caught by an trooper, who put Wheeler in his unmarked police car. Inside the car, a "violent struggle" ensued. The trooper was shot in the leg; Wheeler also was shot. He was taken to a hospital where he died.

column21: Disturbance at an assisted living facility
column36: Williamsburg and James City County Commonwealth's Attorneys
column42: Police were called to a senior living center for a disturbance. When an officers arrived, Anthony Bland, 26, hit one of them with his car, breaking the officer's pelvis. Another officer fired at Bland. Bland got out of the car and charged the officer. The officer shot and killed Bland.

Two officers heard a shotgun shot as they approached Hargrove's house. Police said they confronted Hargrove and told him to drop his weapon. He initially complied, dropping his weapon, but then picked it back up. Officers immediately shot him. He died days later in a hospital.

column14: 9 mm and Tec-9 semi automatic hangun
column42: India Kager, 28, and Angelo Perry were stopped by police searching for Perry in connection with a homicide. When officers approached the vehicle in a parking lot, Perry fired, hitting an officer's shirt sleeve. Police returned fire, killing both Perry and Kager. The couple's 4-month-old son was in the back seat but was unharmed.

India Kager, 28, and Angelo Perry were stopped by police searching for Perry in connection with a homicide. When officers approached the vehicle in a parking lot, Perry fired, hitting an officer's shirt sleeve. Police returned fire, killing both Perry and Kager. The couple's 4-month-old son was in the back seat but was unharmed.

column25: Officers "C, M and CA" (Only initials givven
column26: Officers "C, M and CA" (Only initials givven
column42: Officers were called to Charleston Detron Newby's wife's house for a domestic incident. Police had Newby, 26, in handcuffs at one point, then uncuffed him. Newby stole his wife's car and a chase ensued. He was chased down in an alley and shot by police. Newby was armed but had not fired his weapon.

column17: Suffered from depression, suicidal at times, shot by Norfolk Police 2009
column26: Ziaja * (Ziaja fired the fatal shot) James Edwards and Shaun Kelly
column42: Police responding to a robbery call found the suspect, Daniel Guy Newcomb, 33, at an auto accident site. Newcomb pointed a toy rifle at the officers, who fired 23 shots at Newcomb, all missing him. After a brief standoff, Newcomb again pointed the toy rifle at one of the officers, who shot and killed him.

An off-duty officer was in a bank when Courtney Andrew Holloman, 30, tried to rob it. The officer identified himself and pulled his gun, ordering Hollomon to drop his weapon. When Hollomon didn't drop his gun, the officer fired and killed him.

column23: Virginia Beach Police, Naval Criminal Investigative Services
column26: Brown * (Virginia Beach Police Department) and Agent Suzanne Marsteller (NCIS)
column42: A woman called police to report her husband was trying to harm himself. When police arrived, Shane Whitworth, 30, fled, pointing a gun at the two officers. They shot and killed him.

column23: Shenandoah County Sheriff's Office, Woodstock Police Department
column33: Frazier's neck was cut with a knife. Two Woodstock officers also injured.
column42: Police were called to a house for a domestic disturbance. William Henry Long, 34, got into a struggle with police, slashing an officer on the throat with a knife. Long was shot and killed by police. The officer needed stitches but survived.

column23: Giles County Sheriff's Office, Pearisburg Police Departmen and Virginia State Police
column26: Carter (State Police) * Captain J.N. Shanks Jr., Lt. T.W. Gautier Jr., Sgt. G.C. Tickle, A.E. Hahnlen, S.T. Hutchinson(Giles County Sheriff's Office) and Lt. R.A. Gautier Pearisburg Police Dept.)
column42: Police were attempting to arrest Jonathan Robertson, 31, who was suspected in a robbery and shooting the day before. When they pulled him over, officers exited their vehicle and ordered Robertson out of his truck. Officers said Robertson then raised a gun, and officers began shooting. Robertson was killed in a subsequent shootout.

column23: Montgomery County Sheriff's Department and Christiansburg Police
column26: Egan * and F.W. Gones (Montgomery County Sheriff's Office) and J.H. Belcher (Christianburg)
column42: Police were at Robert Kevin Hughes' home to serve a warrant. Hughes, 49, barricaded himself inside, then tried to escape. During an ensuing chase, he turned and fired at an officer, who returned fire. Two other officers also fired at and hit Hughes. When they approached Hughes he raised his gun and was shot again.

An officer spotted a stolen car in a parking lot and approached it. Wayne S. Lyall, 39, and the officer struggled. Lyall grabbed a gun on the floor of his car. As he turned to fire at the officer, Lyall was shot and killed.

column17: Told police he believed he had mental health issues.
column26: DeBoard * Ryan Bailey (DeBoard fired fatal shot)
column30: Deboard is white, Bailey is black
column42: When answering a call about a man with a gun, police came across Keshawn Dominique Hargrove, 20. Hargrove ran when police arrived, then turned and shot at officers. One officer was struck before another officer shot Hargrove and killed him.

column23: Farmville Police Department, Prince Edward County Sheriff's Office
column42: William Wingfield, 45, had recently been served a protective order from his estranged wife, which also made it illegal for him to possess a firearm. Police were looking for him for allegedly illegally firing a weapon, which led to a car chase. After he shot at police, Wingfield was shot and killed.

column14: A high-heeled shoe wrapped in a shirt to look like a gun
column42: Jataynun Fleming, 22, was a suspect in a murder that happened earlier in the day. Police approached his house and a standoff began. Fleming told officers they were going to have to "shoot it out." When Fleming exited the house with a high-heeled shoe wrapped in a shirt, he was shot and killed.

column39: Charged with first degree murder. Convicted of voluntary manslaughter.
column42: An officer said he stopped William Chapman II, 18, for shoplifting when the unarmed teenager attacked him. The officer shot and killed Chapman.  The officer was found guilty of voluntary manslaughter for shooting Chapman.

column17: Parents said he struggled with mental health issues all his life.
column42: Walter Brown, 29, led police on a chase after they tried to stop him for suspicious activity. He ran into his house. Police say Brown grabbed a gun inside and it was then that a police officer shot and killed him.

column21: Burglary (Denyankin was drunk and pounding on a door)
column42: Kirill Denyakin, 26, was drunk and pounding on an apartment door when an officer approached him. The officer said Denyakin put his hand at his waistband and charged him. The officer fired multiple times, killing Denyakin.

column17: Police also acknowledged at the time of the shooting that officers responding to the call knew he had mental health problems.
column21: Reports of a man pointing a gun at city workers.
column26: Thursby * C. Durham and B. Aguilar
column42: Warren refused to leave his house when police arrived. When they tried to give him a phone to communicate with them, he pointed a gun at the officers and was shot and killed. It was discovered later the gun was not loaded.

Michael Pierce, 23, had a gun on his neighbor's porch. At one point, Pierce placed the gun on his neighbor's chest. Police told Pierce to put the gun down. Instead, he taunted the officers and shot at them. Police returned fire and killed Pierce.

column21: Family called police because he had a knife
column42: David Latham's family called for police help because Latham was wiedling a knife in his home. When officers arrived, they ordered Latham, 35, to drop the knife. When he refused to do so, an officer shot and killed Latham.

column17: Was a CSB client with known mental health issues.
column42: Police were asked to assist social workers in taking Lawrence Faine, 72, into custody for an emergency treatment order. Faine approached an officer with a knife. The officer shot and killed Faine.

column17: Extremely erratic in the weeks before the shooting, references to the Bible and a "dog and lion."
column33: None to Shahsiah but Officer Jones was shot and killed by Brown.
column42: James Andrew Brown, 29, had already shot and killed 17-year-old Mark Rodriguez and a police officer when he crashed his car. An officer tried to subdue Brown and handcuff him. Brown broke free and charged the officer, who then shot and killed Brown.

column33: Officer Matthew Williams was struck by one of Watson's 13 bullets
column42: Joshua Johnson, 22, pulled up to a drive-through window of a Wells Fargo bank in Ghent to cash a forged check. A cashier called police. One officer went to Johnson's car from behind while another drove his cruiser in front of Johnson to block him in. The officer got out of his car and Johnson tried to back up. Fearing for the life of the officer behind Johnson, the officer in front of the car shot and killed Johnson.
Kenneth Smallwood Jr., 20, was spotted breaking into cars. When an officer approached him, Smallwood "floored it," allegedly trying to back over the officer. The officer shot and killed Smallwood.

Marquize Martin, 21, led a police officer on a chase following a report of a stolen car. Martin crashed into a front yard. The officer said Martin accelerated toward him and he had no choice but to shoot. Martin was killed.

After abducting a woman and sexually assaulting her, Robert Christopher Burchfield, 40, got into a standoff with police while still in his car. When police believed Burchfield was about to kill the woman, they shot and killed him.

David Bailey, 35, and a passenger were stopped by police for "two infractions," including stopping at a stoplight past the stop bar. Police said Bailey picked up a gun and started to aim it at police. Two officers shot him.

column23: Henrico County Police, Charles City County Sheriff's Deapartment
column42: Basil Berry, 33, and Eric Roach robbed a jewelry store in James City County, tying up employees and robbing them as well. That led to a manhunt in Henrico County. When police closed in, Berry and Roach fired at them from an SUV. Police returned fire and killed Berry. The car crashed. Roach escaped but was later captured.

column21: Report of armed man barricaded inside his home
column23: Washington County Sheriff's Office, Bristol City Police and Virginia State Police at scene but did not shoot
column42: Police responded to calls of a man barricaded inside his home. After a standoff, police used tear gas on the home. Dennis Morrell, 55, exited through the basement with a gun. Morrell was shot and killed.

column21: Call concerning shots fired during a domestic dispute
column23: Washington County Sheriff's Office and Virginia State Police
column42: Michael Huffman's wife called police because her husband, 56, was shooting at a stray cat from the bathroom window. When police arrived, Huffman was sitting in a chair in the living room with his back to the door. Police told Huffman to drop the gun. Instead, he started to get out of the chair. Huffman was shot in the back and killed.
Cpl. Bray chased Waller following a shooting. Waller pointed his gun at Bray, who shot and killed him.

column17: Was described by people who knew him as mentally unbalanced. One person said he "tried to kill himself plenty of times."
column42: Charles "Zeke" Sponaugle Sr., 52, shot six family members, injuring four and killing two. When he released his dog to attack police and fired at officers, Sponaugle was shot and killed.

column17: History of mental illness and received mental health services prior to shooting.
column21: Woman was acting erratically in Costco
column33: Uninjured - One officer injured by a bullet from Fostern's Gun.
column42: Mhai Scott, 38, was a Costco employee who started acting erratically. When confronted by police at work, she held a large carving knife in one hand and kitchen scissors in the other. She was Tasered but continued moving toward deputies. Scott was shot when an officer "transitioned back to his firearm and fired five rounds," according to the Commonwealth's Attorney's report.

column17: History of mental illness. Was depressed and cutting himself when police arrived on scene.
column35: Purcellville Police Department and Loudoun County Sheriff's Office
column42: Christian Sierra, 17, jumped off a two-story townhouse and threatened to stab himself. Carrying a knife, Sierra he started walking toward a police officer. The officer fired one round at Sierra. When Sierra continued, the officer fired three more rounds, killing Sierra.
Police struggled with Stephen Andre Lee, 22, after a hit-and-run. During the struggle, an officer hung on to Lee's car while it was moving. The officer fired a shot and killed Lee.

Police responded to what turned out to be a murder-suicide or suicide pact: Gary Lee, 54, stabbed his wife, but couldn't stab himself. He tried to end his life by standing on train tracks. When police arrived, Lee pretended a cane was a gun and was shot and killed by SWAT officers.

column21: Struck a police car with a baseball bat
column42: Officers shot and killed Bryant Michael Wieford, 26, after he attacked them with a baseball bat.

column17: Mental issue mentioned in divorce preceedings
column21: Domestic violence against wife, child, mother-in-law
column42: Police responded to a domestic disturbance call to find a woman bleeding in front of her home. She told police that her husband, Travis Williams, 38, was trying to kill her and already had killed her baby and grandmother. Williams lit the house on fire and climbed to the roof armed with a handgun. Police shot and killed him.

column17: Depression, passive aggressive disorder, attention deficit disorder
column20: Spice, often marketed as KD or "herbal incense"
column42: Police showed up at the home of James Wallace, 31, to serve a warrant. Deputies found him in an upstairs room of the house with a knife. They told him to put down the weapon. When he came at the deputies with the knife, one of them shot and killed Wallace.

Smith called police threatening to kill himself with a sword. Police arrived and Smith held a knife to his own throat and a second knife to his side. He advanced toward officers with knives and was shot

column17: History of depression and possibly cut himself.
column21: Hathaway entered the school bleeding and told officer he'd been mugged
column33: Abrasions and contusions across Mulberry’s face and hands
column42: Joshua Hathaway, 19, entered the lobby at a Liberty University building, bleeding. Hathaway told a security guard he had been mugged. He then pulled a mallet from under his shirt. Hathaway and the security wrestled to the ground; Hathaway was shot and killed.

column21: Threatened grocery cashier with hunting knife
column42: Minter pulled a knife on a cashier when his bill was over $40. Later he got into a car chase with police and was shot to death.

column17: Mother reports mental instability from a young age.
column23: Fawuier County Sheriff's Offce and Stafford County Sheriff's Office
column42: Looking for information on a car that had been run into a ditch and abandoned, police visited the home where the vehicle was registered. When police arrived, Evan Newsome, 17, grabbed a knife and locked himself in the house, where he lived with his mother. County deputies entered the home through a side door and said Newsom attacked them with the knife, cutting one of the deputies. Police shot and killed Newsom.

column17: Search warrant stated he suffered from mental health problems
column23: Fauquier County Sheriff's Office, State Police
column42: When the deputies tried to detain Joshua Michael Simpson, 34, on a emergency custody order, he barricaded himself in his home with a gun. After an hours-long standoff, he was shot. Simpson later died in the hospital.

column21: Attempting to serve warrants on Gray
column42: When police tried to serve warrants on Gray Alan Combs Jr., 22, he tried to attack them with a sword. One officer shot Combs with a nonlethal bean bag; another shot Combs with his gun, killed him.
Police responded to a domestic assault call. Gary Dean Carty, 60, pulled out a knife and charged at a deputy. Carty was shot and killed.

Roderick Warren Valentine, 52, got into a fight with Corey Flippen, who pulled a knife and cut Valentine. A police officer tried to break up the fight. Valentine pulled out a gun, shooting Flippen in the arm and the police officer in the hand. The officer returned fire, killing Valentine.

column17: Lived in a home for mentally ill
column42: Following a report of a stabbing, an officer came upon Joseph Croft, 49, who had a knife. When the officer confronted him, Croft moved toward the officer with the knife. Croft was shot and killed.

Harold Daniels, 59, was being questioned at his home about hitting a stop sign with his vehicle. When he couldn't find his keys, Daniels went upstairs in his house. Police followed him. Daniels drew a gun and fired. He was shot and killed.

column21: Pulled over for a suspended license
column42: While driving on a suspended license, Thomas Neil Saunders, 47, was stopped by police. When the officer tried to issue a ticket, Saunders said, "You give me no other choice," and pulled a gun from the console. The officer shot and killed Saunders.

column36: U.S. Attorney in Alexandria, Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, Fairfax Commonwealth's Attorney
column42: Officers responded to a domestic dispute call at the home of John Geer, 46. Two officers stood 15 feet away from Geer and spoke to him for 50 minutes before Geer was shot. One officer said Geer had reached for a gun; other officers dispute that statement.

Delma Towler, 83, called police to report an intruder in her home. She fired holes into the ceiling to scare the intruder. When police arrived, she pointed a gun. An officer shot and killer her. The same officer fatally shot a man in 2008 in Campbell County.

column14: Two letter openers described as knives
column42: A woman in a relationship with Christopher Prevatt, 38, called police to remove Prevatt from the home. When an officer arrived, Prevatt lunged at the deputy with a letter opener. Prevatt was shot and and killed.

column17: Police were trying to serve a emergency custody order on him.
column23: Greensville County Sheriff's Office, Virginia State Police fired weapon
column42: Police were trying to serve an emergency custody order on Jeffrey Adkins, 53. When they arrived, Adkins had a sawed-off shotgun. That led to an hours-long standoff. State police asked Adkins to comply with an order to drop his weapon. When Adkins fired at police, they returned fire, killing him.

column20: Autopsy revealed alcohol and Xanax in his system and a "substantial" level of methamphetamine in his blood.
column42: Max Frye, 40, pointed a gun at his girlfriend and shot at a friend's car. Police arrived and asked Frye to put his gun down 25 times; he eventually did. But Frye later picked up the gun and fired. The officer returned fire, killing him.

column42: Police stopped two men wearing stocking masks. They shot Nicholas Allen Kaelber, 21, after he wielded a handgun.

column42: James Bryant, 28, and other men were fighting near a homeless shelter. Police followed them from a 7-Eleven to the shelter where they used non-deadly force on Bryant. Police finally shot him after he attacked them with a police baton.

Bennett Lee McKay Sr., 49, refused to comply with a deputy's command to put down his handgun. McKay was shot and killed. State police won't release if McKay threatened to kill anyone or if the officer was accompanied.

column42: After Brian McDaniel, 39, assaulted his mother, she asked for a warrant for his arrest. When police arrived to serve the warrants, McDaniel pointed a gun at them. He was shot and killed.

column33: Not injured. Claimed hand stuck in moving car. Jury found claim uncredible.
column39: found guilty of voluntary manslaughter, unlawful shooting at an occupied motor vehicle and shooting into an occupied vehicle causing death
column42: An officer approached Patricia Cook's car after receiving a call about a suspicious person near a school. He shot Cook, 54, four times, including twice from behind, saying his hand was stuck in the car.

An officer stopped to assist Frankie Pitt, 45, who was stopped by the side of the road waving a gas can. The officer realized Pitt was a suspect in a robbery and attempted to arrest him. A struggle for the officer's gun ensued; Pitt was shot and killed.

column21: Wife called to say Ferris was suicidal.
column42: A woman called police because her husband was suicidal. Richard Ferris, 44, got into a standoff with police when they arrived. Police fired at him once early in the standoff, then again when he fired at them a few hours later. Ferris was struck and killed.

column21: Wanted to turn himself in on warrants
column42: Police responded to a call of an attempted suicide. Mario Jordan, 34, shot at police when they arrived; police returned fire. Jordan was struck once, got up and went for his gun again. He was shot again, this time fatally.

Police were called to the home of Jeremy Farley, 39, for a domestic dispute. One officer used a stun gun on Farley. Only one prong hit Farley, and officers noticed he had a gun. Farley fired at the officers, hitting a radio on an officer's uniform. An officer shot and killed Farley.

column23: Buchanan County Sheriff's Office, Virginia State Police on scene but did not shoot, Russel County Sheriff, Tazewell County Sheriff, Wise County Sheriff, U.S. Marshalls, FBI

column42: After trying to light his ex-wife on fire and threatening her with an ax, Richard Bergeron, 37, charged at police, who shot and killed him.

column14: Ruger .357 Revolver, unloaded unbeknownst to police.

column26: Sawyer * (Christiansburg Police) Anthony Marshall (Christiansburg Police) Deputy Clark Jackson (Montgomery Sheriff's Deputy)
column42: Larry Miller, 69, pointed a gun at the the officers following a domestic disturbance call. He was shot and killed.

column33: Officer struck in face by metal pole by Rials-Torres, struck by own taster prong
column42: Alfredo Rials-Torres, 54, was in a domestic dispute with a woman. When confronted by police he attacked them with a metal pole and was shot and killed.

column39: convicted of voluntary manslaughter, initially charged with first degree murder

column17: Treated for depression, was off of his medication

column42: Colby W. Eppard, 18, stole a police officer's car and led more than 15 officers on a chase, firing a gun at them as he drove. He eventually ran into a ditch. He continued to shoot; seven officers returned fire. Eppard was killed.

column42: Gregory A. Rosson Jr., 21, was beating his girlfriend when police arrived. An officer drew his gun and ordered Rosson to stop and stay where he was. Rosson charged the officer, who shot him five times in the chest and once in the neck, killing him.

column26: Turcotte * N.S. Eddington (only Turcotte shot), D.K. Dufault
column42: Police received a report of a woman wielding a sledgehammer. When they arrived, they confronted Tynisha J. Townsend, 22. An officer grabbed Townsend and got his arm stuck in the car. He then shot her in the chest, killing her.

Jamarr Hassell, 18, was chased by police after officers received a call of "shots fired." As he ran away from police, with gun in hand, officers say he turned toward them, putting them in danger. They shot and killed him.
